snippet: After weeks of silence, the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden appealed for help in gaining asylum in Russia as he continued to seek passage to Latin America.
abstract: Edward J Snowden renews plea for Russia to grant him asylum, breaking his silence after three weeks of seclusion at Moscow’s Sheremetyevo Airport; asks human rights officials to petition on his behalf, both to the United States and to Russian Pres Vladimir Putin; says he was forced to turn to Russia for asylum because he could not travel to Latin America safely.

byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY and ANDREW ROTH
byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Peter Baker from Washington; Rick Gladstone from New York; William Neuman from Caracas, Venezuela; Nick Cumming-Bruce from Geneva; and Noah Sneider from Moscow.

lead_paragraph: After weeks of silence, the former N.S.A. contractor Edward J. Snowden appealed for help in gaining asylum in Russia as he continued to seek passage to Latin America.

headline.main: Snowden Renews Plea for Moscow to Grant Asylum
headline.print_headline: Snowden Renews Plea for Moscow To Grant Asylum
